fr:title.text: The category of presheaves is the free cocompletion

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The category of presheaves is the free cocompletion

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Since every presheaf is a colimit of representables, hence a colimit of objects in the image of the Yoneda embedding, and the functor \hat {F} must preserve colimits, there is (up to isomorphism) only one candidate fomula: given a presheaf P, we must have \begin {aligned} \hat {F}P &= \hat {F}(\operatorname *{colim}(\text {el}(P)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xhookrightarrow {y} \hat {C})) \\\\ &= \operatorname *{colim} (\text {el}(P)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xhookrightarrow {y} \hat {C}\xrightarrow {\hat {F}} E) \\\\ &= \operatorname *{colim} (\text {el}(P) \xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xrightarrow {F} E). \end {aligned} By functoriality of colimits, this is well-defined.

By the proof of the density formula, we recognize this as the colimit formula for the Kan extension of F along y. (Indeed, since the Yoneda embedding is fully faithful, this Kan extension is necessarily an isomorphism, so that this extension necessarily makes the triangle commute.)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sheaves in geometry and logic
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @book{maclane-moerdijk-1994, title = {Sheaves in Geometry and Logic: A First Introduction to Topos Theory}, author = {MacLane, S. and Moerdijk, I.}, isbn = {9781461209270}, doi = {10.1007/978-1-4612-0927-0} lccn = {91033709}, series = {Universitext}, url = {https://books.google.com/books?id=LZWLBAAAQBAJ}, year = {1994}, publisher = {Springer New York}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We dedicate this book to the memory of J. Frank Adams. His clear insights have inspired many mathematicians, including both of us. In January 1989, when the first draft of our book had been completed, we heard the sad news of his untimely death. This has cast a shadow on our subsequent work. Our views of topos theory, as presented here, have been shaped by continued study, by conferences, and by many personal contacts with friends and colleagues-including especially O. Bruno, P. Freyd, J.M.E. Hyland, P.T. Johnstone, A. Joyal, A. Kock, F.W. Lawvere, G.E. Reyes, R Solovay, R Swan, RW. Thomason, M. Tierney, and G.C. Wraith. Our presentation combines ideas and results from these people and from many others, but we have not endeavored to specify the various original sources. Moreover, a number of people have assisted in our work by pro viding helpful comments on portions of the manuscript. In this respect, we extend our hearty thanks in particular to P. Corazza, K. Edwards, J. Greenlees, G. Janelidze, G. Lewis, and S. Schanuel.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} E and C\xrightarrow {K} D be functors and suppose that the colimit \operatorname *{colim}(K\downarrow d\xrightarrow {\Pi _C} C\xrightarrow {F} E) exists for each d\in D. Then these colimits define the action on objects of the left Kan extension D\xrightarrow {\operatorname *{Lan}_K F} E, and furthermore the unit of the Kan extension is determined by the colimit cone.
Dually, the limits \operatorname *{lim}(d\downarrow K\xrightarrow {\Pi _C} C\xrightarrow {F} E) define the right Kan extension \operatorname *{Ran}_K F.

Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set be a presheaf for C locally small. Then F is the colimit of the diagram \text {el}(F)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xhookrightarrow {y} \hat {C}, where y is the Yoneda embedding.

fr:title.text: Pointwise Kan extensions along fully faithful functors are isomorphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Pointwise Kan extensions along fully faithful functors are isomorphisms

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The unit of the pointwise Kan extension of a functor F along a fully faithful functor K is an isomorphism.

Let D\xrightarrow {U} C be a functor and c\in C an object. Then a U-free object on c represents the functor C(c, U-). Explicitly, it is an object d\in D equipped with a bijection C(c, Uz)\cong D(d, z) natural in z\in D. In other words, it satisfies the universal property that Fc would have, for a left adjoint F to U.

Dually, a U-cofree object on c represents the functor C(U-, c). Explicitly, it is an object d\in D equipped with a bijection C(Uz, c)\cong D(z, d) natural in z\in D: it satisfies the universal property that Fc would have, for a right adjoint F to U.
A functor is called cocontinuous if it preserves colimits.

fr:title.text: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Right adjoints preserve limits. Dually, left adjoints preserve colimits.

Letting \Delta be the constant diagram functor, we have the following series of natural isomorphisms: \begin {aligned} C^J(\Delta c, GK) &\cong D^J(F\Delta c, K) &&\text {by (1)}\\\\ &\cong D^J(\Delta Fc, K) &&\text {by (2)}\\\\ &\cong D(Fc, \operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the definition of limits}\\\\ &\cong C(c, G\operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the adjunction}. \end {aligned} By definition of limits, this exhibits G\operatorname *{lim}_J K as a limit of GK.
Let J be an index category and let C be J-complete. Then there is a functor C^J \xrightarrow {\operatorname *{lim}_J} C which acts on functors by taking the limit.
Note that this theorem relies on a choice of witnesses to the completeness of C, i.e. a canonical choice of limit of each J-shaped diagram.
A category is cocomplete if it has all small colimits.

fr:title.text: Full and faithfullness of the Yoneda embedding

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Full and faithfullness of the Yoneda embedding

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Yoneda embedding is full and faithful. This result is sometimes conflated with the Yoneda lemma.

Consider a natural transformation yA\xrightarrow {\alpha }yB. By the Yoneda lemma, there is a canonical morphism A\xrightarrow {f}B corresponding to \alpha , which in particular satisfies \alpha _A(1_A) = f. The natural transformation yf = f^* satisfies this condition, and so by the Yoneda lemma is the only morphism to do so. As such, the Yoneda embedding induces exactly the bijection C(A, B) = yBA \cong \hat {C}(yA, yB) established by the Yoneda lemma.
A presheaf on a category C is a contravariant functor C^\text {op}\to Set. The presheaf category \hat {C} is the functor category Set^{C^\text {op}} of presheaves on C.
The Yoneda embedding C\xrightarrow {y}\hat {C} of C into its presheaf category is the functor with action
In other words, it is a curried version of the hom functor.
A natural isomorphism is an isomorphism in a functor category. Explicitly, it is a natural transformation whose components are each isomorphisms.
